application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

Moreover, considering that the solutions of the characteristic function are continuous functions of T and that (1) is asymptotically stable when T = 0, a value T > 0 exists that guarantees asymptotic stability when T < T . The value T can be determined as the timedelay which corresponds to eigenvalues crossing the imaginary axis for ! 2 [0!max; !max]. A further consequence of the system stability under the condition T = 0 is that (0) 6 = 0. Therefore a maximum value for T can be derived from the determination of a range of such that () 6 = 0. This solution search can be restricted to 2 [0; ] considering that e 0j is a periodic function of with period 2 and that (0) = ().

If () 6 = 0, 8 2 [0; ], then (1) is IOD asymptotically stable, otherwise if 9 : ( ) = 0, then (1) is stable under the condition T !max < , as stated by the definition of and the condition jImf gj ! max of Theorem 3. From this condition, the estimation T of the time-delay in Theorem 4 is obtained.

div.head: Unified Formulation of Robotic Systems with Holonomic and Nonholonomic Constraints
Xiaoping Yun and Nilanjan Sarkar
div.p: Abstract-Many robotic systems are subject to nonholonomic as well as holonomic constraints. Rolling contact between two rigid bodies is a typical example of such a system. In this study, a unified state space formulation of robotic systems subject to both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints is presented. The position-level holonomic constraints are first replaced by a set of velocity-level constraint equations that asymptotically converge to the original holonomic constraints. Having represented both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints in a common form, a state space representation of the constrained systems is then developed. A numerical algorithm for implementing the state space representation is also described. The proposed formulation eliminates the need to solve holonomic constraints either analytically or numerically, and ensures that holonomic constraints are always satisfied, particularly in computer simulations. The formulation makes it possible to treat systems with holonomic constraints, with nonholonomic constraints, or with both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints in a unified framework. Two examples are presented to illustrate the application of the unified formulation.
Index Terms-Holonomic constraints, nonholonomic constraints.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Dynamic systems may be classified as constrained and unconstrained. Constraints imposed on a dynamic system may be holonomic, nonholonomic, or both. The subject matter of this paper is dynamic systems that are subject to both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints. A mechanical system with rolling contacts is such an example. Each rolling contact between two rigid bodies is Manuscript recieved January 10, 1997; revised April 23, 1998. This paper was supported by NSF Grants IRI-95-96026, CDA-95-96021, and BES-97-01614, ONR Grant N00014-97-1-0961, University of Hawaii Seed Money Grant 3-90017, and the NPS RIP Grant. This paper was recommended for publication by Associate Editor A. De Luca and Editor A. Goldenberg upon evaluation of the reviewers' comments.
X. Yun is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA 93943-5121 USA (e-mail: yun@ece.nps.navy.mil).
N. Sarkar is with the Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, HI 96822 USA (e-mail: sarkar@wiliki.eng.hawaii.edu).
Publisher Item Identifier S 1042-296X(98)06074-1.

1042-296X/98$10.00 Â© 1998 IEEE characterized by two nonholonomic constraints (the relative tangential velocities at the point of contact must be zero) and one holonomic constraint (two rigid bodies remain in contact with each other) [1].
While the study of rolling contacts in the literature is focused on the treatment of nonholonomic constraints [2]- [5], the treatment of holonomic constraints is generally neglected.

In recent years much effort has been devoted to the development of various methods for treating systems that are subject to holonomic constraints or nonholonomic constraints. Little is available for dealing with systems that are subject to both types of constraints simultaneously. Previous work on nonholonomic systems, holonomic systems, and numerical solutions of constrained systems is briefly reviewed below.

div.head: A. Nonholonomic Systems
div.p: Nonholonomic systems were actively studied in the past several years [6]- [11], owing partly to many interesting applications ranging from space robots [12]- [15], underwater robots [16], [17], wheeled mobile robots/vehicles [18]- [23], grasping [2], [24], [25], and manipulation [5], [26], [27]. Even though one cannot completely enumerate all classes of nonholonomic constraints, a special class of nonholonomic constraints that arise from these applications is characterized by velocity-level equality equations. Dynamic systems that are subject to this class of nonholonomic constraints enjoy an inherent structure that is particularly suitable for state space representations. Both kinematic and dynamic models of such systems can be conveniently transformed into a state space form. From control point of view, in state space form nonholonomic systems can be analyzed using advanced state space control theory. From simulation point of view, they can be numerically integrated using methods developed for ordinary differential equations.

div.head: B. Holonomic Systems
div.p: Holonomic constraints are characterized by equality equations in terms of position variables (or those that can be integrated to positionlevel equations if initially described by velocity-level equations). Much of work on holonomic systems in robotics was discussed in the context of force control [28]- [31], with an emphasis on regulating the Lagrange multiplier. Yoshikawa [28] studied position/force control of manipulators under holonomic constraints. Constraints were differentiated to obtain coordinate axes that are normal to a constraint surface and those that are tangent to the constraint surface. Motion equations of manipulators were projected onto the tangent axes. Contact forces in the normal axes were represented as an algebraic equation. Holonomic constraints were enforced by explicitly controlling contact forces. Yun [29] introduced dynamics into the contact force equations of Yoshikawa's approach [28], making it possible to asymptotically stabilize contact forces. McClamroch and Wang [30] assumed that part of generalized coordinates can be solved in terms of the remaining ones from holonomic constraints. A nonlinear transformation was introduced to transform differentialalgebraic equations of constrained systems into an algebraic equation characterizing the constraint force and an ordinary differential equation on the constraint manifold that does not explicitly depend on the contact force. In a separate work, McClamroch [32] viewed dynamic models of constrained manipulators as singular systems of differential equations. Mills and Goldenberg [31] approached the problem using descriptor variable systems: E _ x = Ax + Bu where E is singular. Since E is singular, there are algebraic constraints among state variables. Results from descriptor variable systems [33] were applied to controller design. This method is only applicable to a neighborhood of an operating point since it is based on a linearized model of the constrained manipulator.

While the work mentioned above addresses the specific problem of position/force control of constrained manipulators, McClamroch [34] studied feedback stabilization of general control systems described by differential-algebraic equations. Conditions on the local stabilization of such systems are established using a state realization approach and a classic linearization (first order approximation) approach.

Udwadia and Kalaba [35] presented a formulation of motion equations that is able to incorporate both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints. This is accomplished by differentiating holonomic constraints twice and nonholonomic constraints once. Both types of constraints are represented at acceleration level. This formulation is analytically appealing, but amplifies the drift problem through differentiation of constraint equations and uses more variables than minimum to describe motion equations.

div.head: C. Numerical Solutions
div.p: Computer simulation is now a common tool in control system design. To simulate a constrained mechanical system, it is necessary to numerically solve differential-algebraic equations. Numerical solutions to differential-algebraic equations are significantly more challenging than those of ordinary differential equations [36]. Differentialalgebraic equations considered in the numerical computation literature take the general form of
When @F @ _

x is singular, there are underlying algebraic equations in (1). Unlike ordinary differential equations _ x = f (x; t), (1) may not necessarily have a solution through every given initial value x(t0). Some differential-algebraic equations are more difficult to solve numerically than others. An index is defined to measure the degree of difficulty or singularity of differential-algebraic equations. The index is defined as the minimum number of times that all or part of (1) must be differentiated with respect to t in order to determine _ x as a function of x and t [36]. According to this definition, ordinary differential equations have an index of zero. Differential-algebraic equations characterizing constrained mechanical systems have an index of three [37]. Differential-algebraic equations with an index greater than one are commonly referred to as higher index systems that are in general difficult to solve numerically.

For mechanical systems with holonomic constraints, the first and easiest approach is to eliminate dependent variables (Lagrange coordinates) from the motion equations. It is then possible to write the motion equation using an ordinary differential equation in terms of a minimal set of independent variables. The elimination process requires solving dependent variables in terms of the independent variables. Assuming the holonomic constraints are independent and continuously differentiable, the implicit function theorem ensures that elimination is analytically possible. Nevertheless, in practical systems, it may be difficult to solve implicit holonomic constraint equations.

Alternatively, holonomic constraints may be differentiated once or twice with respect to time and represented at the velocity or acceleration level. The velocity-level or acceleration-level representation of holonomic constraints can then be integrated with the equations of motion. Differentiation reduces the index of the problem. For example, by replacing the position constraint with the velocity constraint and using appropriate initial conditions, the index of the constrained system is reduced from three to two, with less difficulty in numerical methods. But there are two problems with this approach, namely, enforcement of the constraints (or drift problem) and the satisfaction of the initial condition.

1) First, if the velocity-level constraints are not uniformly satisfied during the course of motion (e.g., in the case of computer simulations), the corresponding position-level constraints will not be satisfied. Further, as soon as the position-level constraints are violated, they cannot be enforced anymore. Campbell and Leimkuhler [38] have demonstrated that in some cases, it is possible to have different eigenvalues of the Jacobian for the original constrained mechanical system and the differentiated form. As a result, the differentiated form may be less well behaved numerically. This numerical degradation is more noticeable if the Jacobian is nearly nonsingular and if there are rapidly oscillating or fast transients appearing in the constraints. 2) Second, the system trajectory must start from an initial condition that exactly satisfies the holonomic constraints. This is, in general, not a problem in the physical implementation of controllers, but is a serious problem in the computer simulation of controllers. Leimkuhler et al. [39] studied the consistent initialization problem and introduced consistency conditions. A numerical algorithm was developed by approximating the consistency equations by finite differences. It is shown that many solvers for differential-algebraic equations become extremely inefficient when the initial values are inconsistent. To eliminate the drift problem, Gear et al. [40] suggested a stabilization formulation. Their method explicitly enforces both position and velocity level constraints by utilizing an additional Lagrange multiplier. Although such a formulation eliminates drift problem, it is found out [37] that it can be very inefficient and poorly conditioned. Overdetermined differential-algebraic equations, where the original constrained system is augmented by both velocity and acceleration constraints, have been investigated by FÃ¼hrer and Leimkuhler [41]. Using the Moore-Penrose pseudo-inverse to solve this system is mathematically equivalent to the stabilization method proposed in [40], however, effective implementations using generalized inverses to solve such an overdetermined system remain underdeveloped [42]. Another approach to eliminating drift is to use Baumgarte's stabilization method [43], [44] that will be discussed in detail in Section III-D.

div.head: D. Proposed Approach
div.p: It is clear that there does not exist a single method that solves all the problems concerning the solution of differential-algebraic equations representing constrained mechanical systems. It is extremely difficult to solve constrained systems at position level because of high index. On the other hand, differentiating the constraint at higher level introduces drift into the solution. If drift must be avoided, the solution becomes very inefficient. Additionally, numerical methods that are developed to solve differential-algebraic equations do not consider control inputs, and thus do not automatically lend themselves to a control formulation (e.g., state-space formulation) of the constrained mechanical systems. Methods that seek to formulate constrained mechanical systems for the control purpose often model the system as a singular differential equation that is very difficult and complicated to solve.

In this paper, we present a unified state space formulation of systems subject to both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints. The position-level holonomic constraints are first replaced by a set of velocity-level constraint equations that asymptotically converge to the original holonomic constraints. By doing so, holonomic and nonholonomic constraints are represented in a common form at the velocity level. The combined velocity constraints are incorporated with the motion equations to derive a state space representation, following a similar procedure previously developed for nonholonomic systems.

In addition to its main contribution of providing a unified treatment for systems with holonomic constraints, systems with nonholonomic constraints, and systems with both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints, a numerical algorithm for implementing the state space representation is described. The proposed formulation also eliminates the need to solve holonomic constraints either analytically or numerically, and ensures satisfying holonomic constraints, particularly in computer simulations. Another benefit of the formulation is that it does not assume or require that holonomic constraints always be satisfied. Consequently, the proposed formulation is able to deal with transitions from noncontact to contact and vice versa.

In summary, the contributions of this paper are three fold. It provides a unified state space control formulation to mechanical systems subject to holonomic and nonholonomic constraints; it solves the problem of consistent initialization; and it offers a numerical algorithm to solve constrained mechanical systems.

The paper is organized as follows. Section II describes motion and constraint equations necessary for subsequent development. Section III is devoted to four different approaches to holonomic constraints. The proposed unified formulation of holonomic and nonholonomic systems is presented in Section IV. Section V details two examples. Some discussion on the proposed formulation is provided in Section VI.

div.head: II. MOTION EQUATIONS OF CONSTRAINED SYSTEMS
A. Nonholonomically Constrained Systems
div.p: We consider mechanical systems that are subject to m velocitylevel equality type of nonholonomic constraints characterized by

where q is the n-dimensional generalized coordinates, B(q) is an m 2 n dimensional matrix with m n. Since the constraints are assumed to be nonholonomic, ( 2) is not integrable. It will be assumed that these constraints are independent. In another words, B(q) has rank m. It is noted that most nonholonomic constraints encountered in mechanical systems, including rolling constraints, are in the form of (2).
Using the Lagrange multiplier rule, the equations of motion of nonholonomically constrained systems are governed by [45] M(q) q + V (q; _ q) + G(q

where M(q) is the n 2 n dimensional positive definite inertia matrix, V (q; _ q) is the n-dimensional velocity-dependent force vector, G(q) is the the gravitational force vector, u is the r-dimensional vector of actuator force/torque, E(q) is the n 2 r dimensional matrix mapping the actuator space into the generalized coordinate space, and n is an m-dimensional vector of Lagrange multipliers.

It has been established that nonholonomic systems described by the motion equation ( 3) and constraint equation ( 2) have a canonical state space representation [8], [10], [46]. The state vector consists of the generalized coordinates q and a set of pseudovelocities (t) = [1 2 1 1 1 n0m], where n is the number of the generalized coordinates and m is the number of the constraints.

div.head: B. Holonomically Constrained Systems
div.p: We now assume that mechanical systems are subject to k holonomic constraints characterized by
The equations of motion of the holonomically constrained system can also be obtained by using the Lagrange multiplier rule. They are given by [45] M(q) q + V (q; _q) + G(q) = E(q)u + J T (q) h (5
where h is a k-dimensional vector of Lagrange multipliers, and J(q)
is the Jacobian of the holonomic constraints, i.e., J(q) = @C(q) @q :

A natural question is how to represent holonomically constrained systems in state space. Unlike nonholonomic systems, there is not a "canonical" state space representation for holonomic systems. There are a number of ways by which holonomic systems can be represented in state space. Each of them is described in the following section, along with their advantages and disadvantages.

Remark 1: We assumed that nonholonomic constraints are given by velocity-level equation ( 2) and holonomic constraints are described by position-level equation ( 4). In practical problems, both types of constraints may be described at velocity level. If both types of constraints are represented in the form of ( 2), the number of holonomic and nonholonomic constraints can be determined by using the Frobenius Theorem [22]. Briefly, let 1 be the distribution spanned by the null space of B(q), and 1 3 be the smallest involutive distribution containing 1. It is clear that n 0 m = dim(1) dim(1 3 ). There are three possibilities.
1) If 1 itself is involutive, i.e., dim(1) = dim(1 3 ), all m constraints are in fact holonomic.
2) If dim(1 3 ) = n, i.e., 1 3 spans the entire space, all m constraints are nonholonomic.

3) If dim(1 3 ) = n 0 k; k out of m constraints are holonomic and the remaining ones are nonholonomic. If holonomic constraints, initially represented as velocity-level equations, are difficult to integrate into position-level equations, the best that one can do is to enforce these holonomic constraints at velocity level by treating them in the same way as nonholonomic constraints.

div.head: A. Direct Elimination
div.p: If the holonomic constraints described by (4) are independent and continuously differentiable, then k out of n generalized coordinates, in principle, can be locally solved in terms of the rest n 0k variables based on the implicit function theorem. Let us, in such a case, partition q into two blocks q = q v q d where q d is k-dimensional dependent variables, and q v is (n 0 k)dimensional independent variables. Based on the implicit function theorem, there is a local function (1) such that q d = (qv): (6) Using this relationship, the dependent variable q d can be eliminated from motion equations [7], [30], [47], [48].

Remark 2: The direct elimination method described above is preferred if it can be carried out at all. In practical applications, there are difficulties that may prevent the use of this method, some of which are listed below.
1. The implicit function theorem ensures the existence of a local function defined in (6). In practice, it may not be possible to obtain such a function at all.
2. Even if q d can be solved in terms of qv, there may be a problem of singularity. For example, if the holonomic constraint equation ( 4) is given by q1q2 + q3q4 = 0

and q 4 is chosen as the dependent variable q d . q 4 can be solved in terms of q1; q2, and q3, but there is a singularity when q3 is equal to zero. In other words, q d can be solved locally, but it cannot be solved globally. 3. There is another problem of multiple solutions, for example, if the holonomic constraint equation ( 4) is given by
where is a constant, or is given by l1 sin(q1) + l2 sin(q1 + q2) + l3 = 0
where l i are constants.

4. Finally, by using the direct elimination method, it is assumed that the holonomic constraints are always satisfied. If for any reason the holonomic constraints are not satisfied over any period of time, the reduced order equations of motion derived by the direct elimination method are not valid. They do not characterize the motion of the mechanical system during that period of time. If these equations are used for simulation, the resulting motion trajectory during that period of time and thereafter may not be correct.

div.head: B. Velocity-Level Constraints
div.p: In this method, the holonomic constraint equation ( 4) is differentiated once and is represented at velocity level in the form of dC(q) dt = 0 ) J(q) _q = 0 (10) where J(q) = @C(q) @q . The velocity-level constraints, (10), are equivalent to the position-level constraints, (4), provided that the initial condition of the system q 0 = q(t 0 ) is a valid one, namely, C(q 0 ) = 0.

Since the velocity-level constraint equation is exactly in the same form as the nonholonomic constraints considered in Section II-A, the holonomically constrained system can be represented in state space using the same procedure for nonholonomic systems described in Section II-A. Using this procedure, the dependent position variables are not eliminated. The dimension of the state vector is (2n 0 k).
Remark 3: There are two problems with this methods concerning the initial condition and the enforcement of the constraints.

1. As stated above, the velocity-level constraint equation is equivalent to the original position-level constraint equation only if the system starts from a valid initial condition. To use this method, particularly in computer simulations, one must numerically solve the system of nonlinear equations C(q) = 0 for a valid initial q 0 .

2. Once the holonomic constraints are violated in a computer simulation, they cannot be enforced. The violation can occur, for example, if the initial condition is not a valid one, or the velocity-level constraints are not strictly satisfied due to numerical inaccuracy.

div.head: C. Acceleration-Level Constraints
div.p: In this method, the holonomic constraint equation ( 4) is differentiated twice to obtain B(q) q + _ B _ q = 0:

The generalized acceleration q is then partitioned into two blocks, the (n 0 k)-dimensional independent acceleration qv and the kdimensional dependent acceleration q d . The matrix B(q) is also partitioned according to the partition of q. Equation ( 11) is then written as
div.formula: [B v (q) B d (q)] q v q d = 0 _ B _ q: (12
div.p: The partition is carried out in such a way that B d (q) is of full rank, which may require to re-order the variables. From ( 12) the dependent accelerations can be solved in terms of independent ones
div.formula: q d = B 01 d (q)[0B v (q) q v 0 _ B _ q]:(13)
div.p: Combining ( 13) and motion equation ( 5), we have (n + k) linear equations with (n + k) unknowns, qv; q d , and h . Eliminating q d and h , the holonomically constrained system is finally expressed by (n 0 k) equations in terms of qv [49] M (q) q v + V (q; _ q) + Ä(q) = Ã(q)u:

If one is merely interested in simulating the constrained system, ( 14) can be used in two different ways [49]. One way is to: 1) integrate ( 14); 2) compute the dependent velocities using _ q d = 0B 01 d (q)Bv(q) _ qv; 3) compute the k-dimensional dependent variable q d by applying numerical root-finding on the holonomic constraint equation (4) [49], [50]. The other way is to:
1) solve qv from (14);
2) compute q d from (13); 3) integrate to obtain q and _ q.

Both of these methods are sufficient for numerically simulating dynamic behaviors of the constrained system. Nevertheless, if one is also concerned with designing feedback control, a state space formulation will facilitate the design process because advanced control methods are mostly developed in state space. Even though the constrained system is now characterized by reduced (n 0 m) equations, it is not sufficient to use a state vector composed of qv and _ q v . However, it is possible to use a state vector
to establish a state equation of the following form for the constrained system:
The vector f(x) and the matrix g(x) are derived as follows:
Finally f(x) and g(x) are given by
This method faces the same problems as the velocity-level constraint method.

div.head: D. Stabilization Method
div.p: Three methods have been described above. Their use in practical applications is severely limited due to the problems associated with each method. To circumvent these problems, we suggest the following method which is motivated by Baumgarte's work [44]. We replace the holonomic constraint equation ( 4) with _ C(q) + C(q) = J(q) _ q + C(q) = 0; > 0: (17) When holonomic constraints are satisfied, i.e., C(q) = 0, the above equation is equivalent to the original holonomic constraints. When they are not satisfied, we impose constraints described by ( 17) onto the mechanical system. These constraints converge to holonomic constraints as seen below.
For any arbitrary initial condition q o , which may or may not necessarily satisfy the holonomic constraint equation ( 4), let C o = C(qo). The solution of ( 17) is given by C(t) = Co exp(0t):
For any positive ; C(t) goes to zero as the time t goes to infinity.

Therefore, even starting from an initial condition that does not satisfy holonomic constraints, the use of ( 17) ensures that holonomic constraints will eventually be satisfied. This is also true if holonomic constraints are initially satisfied but are violated some time later. The rate of convergence is determined by , which can be appropriately chosen based on specific applications. With those new constraints, the holonomically constrained system is then governed by M(q) q + V (q; _ q) + G(q) = E(q)u + J T (q) h J(q) _ q + C(q) = 0:

A state space representation can be derived using the procedure for nonholonomic systems discussed in Section II-A, with certain modifications. Instead of presenting the modified procedure here, it is discussed in the next section, where both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints are considered together. It is noted that Baumgarte's method was proposed for stabilizing numerical solutions of constrained systems. The new use of Baumgarte's method in the present context leads to a unified formulation of holonomically and nonholonomically constrained systems. This method may be explained in terms of manifolds. For a given initial condition (q(0); _ q(0)) such that J(q(0)) _ q(0) = 0, the trajectory belongs to the manifold defined by C(q) = C(q(0)):

Replacing the holonomic constraints by ( 17), a particular manifold, defined by C(q) = 0, is made invariant and attractive. For any initial condition, this method generates a trajectory that does not remain on one manifold but crosses different manifolds, and exponentially converges to this particular manifold.

div.head: IV. A UNIFIED FORMULATION OF HOLONOMICALLY AND NONHOLONOMICALLY CONSTRAINED SYSTEMS
A. State Space Formulation
div.p: In this section, we consider the case in which the system is subject to m nonholonomic constraints characterized by ( 2) and k holonomic constraints described by (4). For reasons discussed early, the holonomic constraint equation (4) will be replaced by (17). Using the Lagrange multiplier rule, the equations of motion of the system under consideration are given by M(q) q + V (q; _ q) + G(q) = E(q)u + J T (q) h + B T (q) n (19

where h is the k-dimensional Lagrange multiplier associated with the holonomic constraints, and n is the m-dimensional Lagrange multiplier associated with the nonholonomic constraints. Combining ( 17) and ( 2), we have the following velocity-level equation:
A(q) _q = a(q) (20) where A(q) = J(q) B(q) ; a(q) = 0C(q) 0 :
Letting = [ T h T n ] T , we may rewrite the motion equation (19) as follows:
M (q) q + V (q; _q) + G(q) = E(q)u + A T (q):

In what follows, the holonomically and nonholonomically constrained system is represented in state space. Equation (20) represents a system of (k + m) linear equations with _q being the vector of unknowns. Since the number of equations is less than that of unknowns, it has infinitely many solutions. Let (q) be a particular solution of (20), i.e., A(q)(q) = a(q):
Let S(q) be an n 2(n 0k 0m) dimensional full rank matrix whose column space is in the null space of A(q), i.e., A(q)S(q) = 0:

The general solution of ( 20) is then given by _q = S(q)(t) + (q) (24) for any smooth vector (t). Differentiating ( 24) once, we have q = S(q) _ (t) + _ S(q)(t) + _(q) S(q) _(t) + (q; ) (25) where (q; ) = _ S(q)(t) + _(q). Pre-multiplying ( 21) by S T (q) and noting that S T A T = 0, we get S T (q)M(q) q + S T (q)V (q; _q) + S T (q)G(q) = S T (q)E(q)u: (26) Replacing q in (26) by the most right hand side of (25), we obtain T MS _ + S T M + S T V + S T G = S T Eu: (27) Let the state vector be x = [q T T ] T . Using this state vector, we may represent (27) in the following standard control system: _x = _q _ = S + 0(S T MS) 01 (S T M + S T V + S T G) + 0 (S T MS) 01 S T E u (28) or simply _x = f (x) + g(x)u (29) where f (x) and g(x) can directly be identified. Given a dynamic system that is subject to both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints, the preceding derivation suggests a unified approach by representing the system in the standard form in state space. This allows us to apply the state space analysis and design techniques to the control of the constrained systems. For example, the differential geometric control theory [51] may be utilized to investigate feedback linearization of the constrained systems. If at least one constraint is nonholonomic (that is, m > 0), it has been shown that the constrained system is not input-state linearizable [46]. Consequently, input-output linearization has been pursued in the practical system design [20]- [22], [46], [52].

div.head: B. Numerical Algorithm
div.p: In this subsection, we present an algorithm for numerically computing all the terms in the state equation (28). The algorithm assumes that the constraint equations are linearly independent, that is, A(q) has the constant rank of (n 0 k 0 m). The algorithm is mainly to show the computability of the state space formulation, and is not optimized in any sense.
Step 1: Specify the initial conditions q(0) and _q(0).

In physical systems, they are measurements of the generalized coordinates and the generalized velocities at the initial time t = 0. In computer simulations, they are the initial assignments (or guesses) of the generalized coordinates and the generalized velocities at the initial time t = 0. It is noted that the initial conditions do not necessarily satisfy the constraint equation (20). It is also noted that the initial conditions specified in this step are not the initial state vector x(0), which is computed in Step 3.
Step 2: Compute S(q) and (q).

In simple systems such as a two-wheel mobile robot [22], S(q) is analytically solved in symbolic form. In general when an analytical solution is not possible, it can be numerically solved using the following algorithm.

Treating _q as the vector of unknowns, ( 20) can be solved using the Moore-Penrose inverse [53], [54] _q = [I 0 A + (q)A(q)] + A + (q)a(q) H(q) + A + (q)a(q) (30) where I is the n 2 n dimensional identity matrix, and A + (q) is the Moore-Penrose inverse of A(q) given by A + (q) = A T (q)(A(q)A T (q)) 01 : (31) Equation ( 30) is similar to (24), but not exactly the same, as seen below. Since A + a is a solution of the constraint equation (20), we may set it to , that is, (q) = A + (q)a(q):

However, H(q) = [I 0 A + (q)A(q)] is not yet S(q) in ( 24) since they are of different dimensions. S(q) is n 2 (n 0 k 0 m) whereas H(q) is an n 2 n square matrix. S(q) is of full rank but H(q) is not. Notice that we used instead of in (30). The rank of H(q) is (n 0 k 0 m) [53]. All the columns of H(q) are in the null space of A(q). Any (n 0 k 0 m) linearly independent columns of H(q) can be chosen for S(q). But it may create discontinuity in if different set of linearly independent columns are chosen at different iterative steps without following a consistent rule.
To remedy this problem, we compute the singular value decomposition of H(q) using a standard numerical routines such as ZSVDC( ) of Linpack [55] or svd( ) of MATLAB [56] to obtain

where U and V are n 2n orthogonal matrices, and 1 is the diagonal matrix 1 = diagf 1 ; 2 ; 111; n0k0m ; 0;111; 0g with the singular values i > 0, i = 1;2;111;n 0 k 0 m. Let 1; 2; 1 11;n denote the column vectors of U , i.e.,

div.head: U = [1 2 111 n]:
div.p: Since AH = A(U 1V T ) = 0 and V is an orthogonal matrix, it is easy to conclude that AU 1 = 0. Because of the structure of matrix 1, it follows that the first n 0 k 0 m columns of U are in the null space of matrix A, i.e., A i = 0; i = 1;2;111;n 0 k 0 m:
Thus we may choose S(q) as the first (n 0 k 0 m) columns of U matrix S(q) = [ 1 2 111 n0k0m ]: (35) It is obvious that S(q) is of full rank since U is orthogonal.

Step 3: Compute initial state x(0). The state vector is composed of q and . q(0) is given in Step 1. (0) is computed from solving _ q(0) = S(q(0))(0) + (0) (36) in which _ q(0) is also given in Step 1, and S(q(0)) and (0) are computed from Step 2. If _ q(0) satisfy the constraint equation, (36) represents a system of consistent linear equations with a unique solution (0). Otherwise, a least-square solution is found.
Step 4: Compute M(q); V (q; _ q); G(q), and E(q).

The expression for these matrices/vectors are given from the motion equation (19). As long as the values of q and _ q are available, they can be directly computed. The value of q is available as part of the state vector x. In the first iteration, the value of _ q is given in
Step 1. In the subsequent iterations, the value of _ q is updated using the _ q = S(q) + (q), where S and are computed in Step 2, and is a part of the state vector.
Step 5: Compute (q; ). The vector (x) is defined in (25) as (q; ) = _ S(q)(t) + _ (q):

If a closed-form, symbolic representation of S(q) and (q) is not available and their values are numerically computed in Step 2, it would require numerically differentiating S(q) and (q) in order to compute . Since numerical differentiation is not desirable, an alternative method is described in what follows.
Differentiating both sides of constraint equation ( 20), one obtains A(q) q = _ a(q) 0 _ A(q) _ q (37)
It is reasonable to assume that the constraint equation itself is differentiable, i.e., A(q) and a(q) are both differentiable. Using the Moore-Penrose inverse again, one may solve q in (37)
Comparing the above equation with (25) and noting the computation of S(q) in Step 2, it follows that:

with _ q being updated by _ q = S(q) + (q). Step 6: Compute f(x) and g(x). Finally, f(x) and g(x) are computed from (28) by assembling together all the matrices and vectors. The state equation is integrated using standard integration routines. The subsequent iterations are performed by repeating Steps 2 through 6 (and skip Step 3, of course).

div.head: A. Example 1: Rolling Spheres
div.p: In this example we model the rolling motion of one small sphere on the outer, rough surface of a large sphere as shown in Fig. 1.

We attach a fixed coordinate frame XY Z at the center of the large sphere. Let be the latitude of the center of the rolling sphere below the equator and be the longitude, measured from the X-axis. Let be the distance from the origin to the center of the small sphere. Let us also assume the mass and the radius of the small sphere be m and r, respectively. Therefore the moment of inertia, I is given by I = Ixx = Iyy = Izz = 2 5 mr 2 : The position coordinates for the center of the small sphere are x = cos cos ; y = cos sin ; z = 0 sin :
Let us define the orientation of the small sphere by the Euler angles

; and , where the rotations are in the following order: is about the body-fixed z axis, is about the body-fixed x axis and is about the body-fixed z axis. In such a case, the angular velocity of the sphere is
div.formula: ! = _ sin sin + _ cos _ sin cos 0 _ sin _ cos + _ :
div.p: Dynamic Equations: The total kinetic energy of the small sphere is

In the absence of gravity, the Lagrangian L is equal to the kinetic energy T . The dynamic equations of motion are obtained by applying Lagrange's equations of motion d dt @L @ _ qi 0 @L @qi = 0 to the above kinetic energy with q = [ ] T . The resulting equations of a free sphere without external forces applied to it are given by M(q) q + V (q; _ q) = 0
Using method for representing the holonomic constraints as described before, we write the holonomic constraint _ + [ 0 (R + r)] = 0 (43) where is any positive number.

In order to maintain rolling motion, the tangential velocities of the contact point must be zero. Expressing these velocities in terms of the generalized coordinates and the generalized velocities, they are given by (R + r) _ 0 r( _ sin cos 0 _ sin ) = 0 (44) (R + r) _ 0 r( _ sin sin 0 _ cos ) = 0: (45) These two constraints are nonholonomic. Now we write the constraints, both holonomic and nonholonomic, in the form A(q) _ q = a(q)
where A(q) = = _ = 0 be a particular solution (q) such that the equation A(q)(q) = a(q) is satisfied. We choose the derivative of the Euler angles as our (t) vector. Therefore
The null space S(q) of the constraint matrix A(q) corresponding to this particular choice of (t) is S(q) = 0 0 0 k sin cos 0k sin 0 k sin sin kcos
where k = r
R+r .

Thus we have derived all the relevant matrices required to represent the problem in the state space. Since a closed-form expression of S(q) and (q) is available in this case, _ S(q) and _ (q) can be obtained by direct differentiation, which leads to more efficient numerical implementation than the algorithm presented in Section IV-B.

Results: We have performed computer simulations to simulate the rolling of the small sphere on the outer surface of the large sphere. We have used r = 0.05 m and R = 0.55 m for the results presented here. has been taken to be 10.0. We have simulated two particular scenarios. First we have used the stabilized form of holonomic constraint equation. We start from a no-contact initial condition. The holonomic constraint engenders the contact after a small interval (based on the value of ). It then maintains contact. At time t = 5 s, the contact is broken by external means, which is realized by displacing the large sphere in the simulation. Because of the structure of the holonomic constraint, the contact state is regained soon as shown in the top left plot of Fig. 2. The remaining two plots in Fig. 2 show how the other variables change as a part of the rolling motion. For the second scenario, we used the exact holonomic constraint equation (41). We start with a contact configuration. Then at t = 5 s, we break the contact as before. But in this case, because there is no stabilization properties incorporated into the holonomic constraint equation, the contact in the simulation is not regained, which is apparent from Fig. 3.

The objective of this simulation exercise is to show that if holonomic constraints are violated in numerical simulations, the use of the original holonomic constraint equation will not able to enforce the constraints afterward. On the other hand, using the formulation described in the previous sections, holonomic constraints will be enforced.

div.head: B. Example 2: Two-Link Manipulator
div.p: This example illustrates the utility of the proposed state space formulation for handling systems with holonomic constraints, and show how holonomic constraints are enforced even if they are initially not satisfied. For simplicity, we consider a planar two-link manipulator whose end point is constrained to a frictionless, circular surface. Link 1 is hinged to the ground with one revolute joint. Link 2 is passively connected to link 1 with a revolute joint. So this is a The equations of motion for this manipulator are easy to derive and also can be found in any robotics textbook.

We will however not use the standard motion equations. We will follow a different approach to demonstrate the use of the stabilization method for holonomic constraints. We first write the motion equations of link 1 and link 2 separately, and then join them together with two holonomic constraints. Even though this example is simple, the methodology is equally applicable to more complex systems.

Dynamic Equations: Since link 1 is hinged to the ground, it has one degree of freedom. Its motion equation is given by I 1 1 = 1 0 m 1 gl c1 cos 1 (46) where 1 is the joint angle, m 1 is the mass, I 1 is the moment of inertia, and 1 is the joint torque. All other notations are illustrated in Fig. 4. Before link 2 is connected to link 1, it is free to move in the plane and has three degrees of freedom. Its equations of motion are given by m 2

I 2 2 = 0 (49) where (x 2 ; y 2 ) is the coordinates of the center of gravity of link 2, m2 is the mass, and I2 is the moment of inertia. These equations can be written in the matrix form as: Constraint Equations: The two links are now connected by a revolute joint going through point A on link 1 and point B on link 2. It is assumed that the joint is passive, i.e., there is no actuator. The coordinates of point A in the world coordinate frame are given by pA = l1 cos 1 l 1 sin 1 (50) and those of point B are described by p B = x 2 0 l c2 cos 2 y2 0 lc2 sin 2 :
div.formula: M (q) q + V (q; _ q) + G(q) = E(q)u with q = 1 x 2 y2
div.p: The two holonomic constraints characterizing the revolute joint are p A = p B :

In addition to these two constraints, the end point of the manipulator is constrained to a frictionless, circular surface centered at the pivoting point of link 1 with radius l3 = 2.5 m. This imposes an additional holonomic constraint characterized by
These three constraints can be written together in the form of ( 4)
div.formula: C(q) = c 1 (q) c2(q) c 3 (q) = 0l 1 cos 1 + x 2 0 l c2 cos 2 0l1 sin 1 + y2 0 lc2 sin 2 l 2 3 0 l 2 1 0 l 2 2 + 2l 1 l 2 cos( + 1 0 2 ) = 0(53)
div.p: and the corresponding Jacobian is given by
div.formula: J(q) = l1 sin 1 1 0 lc2 sin 2 0l 1 cos 1 0 1 0l c2 cos 2 J 31 0 0 J 34(54)
div.p: Results: The length, mass, and inertial parameters of the two links used in the simulation are: L 1 = 2.0, L c1 = 1.0, L 2 = 1.0, L c2 = 0.5, m 1 = 10.0, m 2 = 6.0, I 1 = 3.0, I 2 = 2.0. The unit for length is meters, and that of mass is kilograms. The stabilization factor is chosen to be 5.0. The simulation codes are written in Matlab Toolbox SIMULINK. The fifth order Runge-Kutta integration routine is used with the integration step setting to 0.01 s.
The simulation is conducted with the following initial state:

With this initial state value, point A and point B do not coincide, and the end point does not touch the constraint surface. Therefore, the holonomic constraints are initially not satisfied. The input u is set to zero. Thus the motion of the system is completely under the influence of gravity forces. The simulation results are plotted in Fig. 5. The top left plot shows the X-Y view of the two link movement during the first 1.5 s. It is noted that the two links are initially disconnected, and the end point is not in contact with the constraint surface. The top right plot depicts the joint angle trajectories. Since no joint torque is applied, the system acts as a double pendulum. The two bottom plots show the values of 5. Simulation results of the two-link manipulator with the end-point constrained to a frictionless circular surface under the influence of gravity forces.
constraints c 1 (q); c 2 (q), and c 3 (q). Once again, it is observed that the constraints are initially not satisfied, but are enforced after about 1.0 s.

It is worth mentioning the choice of values for . In the previous example, was chosen to be 10.0. The holonomic constraint was enforced in less than 0.5 s. In this example, is 5.0, and the convergence time is about 1.0 s. Additional simulations with different values of indicated that the convergence time is about five times of 1=. This is because the stabilized holonomic constraint equation represents a first-order system, and its time constant is 1=. Given a step input, it takes about four to five times of the time constant for a first-order system to converge to its steady state.

div.head: VI. DISCUSSION
div.p: While the main contribution of the this work is the development of a unified formulation for holonomic and nonholonomic systems, it also brings in other benefits that are summarized below.

1) As discussed above, the holonomic constraints, (4), in general appear as implicit functions of q. is if possible at all, to solve implicit functions to represent the dependent variables in terms of the independent ones. The method described in Section III-D eliminates the need to solve the implicit functions, and at the same time ensures that the constraints are satisfied. The original purpose of Baumgarte's method [44] was exclusively for stabilizing holonomic constraints due to numerical errors. It is not until this work that the method finds its utility in leading to a unified treatment to holonomic and nonholonomic systems.

2) The proposed formulation does not require to obtain initial conditions that satisfy C(q) = 0. Starting from any initial condition, the approach ensures that the holonomic constraints will eventually be satisfied. Similarly, if the holonomic constraints are not satisfied in the middle of motion trajectories for any reason, it enforces the satisfaction of the constraints. This is particularly useful for computer simulations of constrained systems. 3) A numerical algorithm is described for implementing the state space model or any model-based controller. The core step of the algorithm is the computation of _ S(q) and _ (q). It circumvents the problem of symbolically or numerically differentiate S(q) and (q). The algorithm is equally applicable to nonholonomic systems described in Section II-A. 4) The type of nonholonomic constraints described by ( 2) is catastatic. The unified formulation can easily accommodate acatastatic constraints which have the form of B(q) _ q = b(q) (56) or equivalently B(q) dq = b(q) dt:

All remains intact in the formulation except that the zero in the lower half of a(q) in ( 20) is replaced by b(q). 5) The formulation overcomes the difficulties of singularity and multiple solutions encountered by the direct elimination method. 6) The formulation represents holonomic and nonholonomic systems in state space, which makes it possible and easy to apply the state space control methods. 7) Finally, the formulation does not assume that holonomic constraints are always satisfied. It can treat transitions from noncontact to contact, and vice versa.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: We presented a unified formulation for treating systems subject to both holonomic and nonholonomic constraints. The constrained systems are represented in state space, which allows one to analyze and synthesize such systems by employing well-developed state space methods. Because the formulation uses a stable first-order differential equation to replace algebraic holonomic constraint equations, it reduces the numerical instability of holonomic constraints that occurs in computer simulations, and eliminates the need to solve multiple nonlinear holonomic constraint equations either analytically or numerically. Since it does not assume or require that holonomic constraints are always satisfied, it is able to deal with transitions from noncontact to contact, and vice versa. The two examples demonstrated the usefulness of the formulation.

figure.figDesc: Constraint Analysis: Let the radius of the large sphere be R. In order to maintain contact, the following holonomic constraint has to be satisfied 0 (R + r) = 0:
